summary: This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, dated August 8, 2019, which designates executors and successor executors for his estate and bequeaths all his property to the trustees of The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust. It outlines extensive powers granted to the executors for managing the estate. This is the final pages of Jeffrey E. Epstein's Last Will and Testament, dated January 18, 2019. It details tax apportionment clauses, definitions, and the execution and witnessing of the document in New York and Florida.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The individual whose will is being executed; the document outlines the disposition of his estate and tax obligations.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Appointed as one of the primary executors of Jeffrey Epstein's will.

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.context: Appointed as one of the primary executors of Jeffrey Epstein's will alongside Darren K. Indyke.

persons.name: Kathryn H. Ruemmler
persons.context: Designated as the successor executor if either primary executor fails to qualify or serve.

persons.name: Amanda Devine
persons.context: Notary Public for the State of Florida who notarized the execution of the will on January 18, 2019.

connections.description: Epstein appointed Indyke as an executor of his will, granting him fiduciary authority over the estate.
Epstein appointed Kahn as an executor of his will, granting him fiduciary authority over the estate.
Epstein designated Ruemmler as the successor executor to take over if the primary executors cannot serve.
Both are appointed as co-executors of Epstein's estate, required to act unanimously on certain decisions.

events.title: Execution of Epstein's Will
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signed his last will and testament, designating executors and outlining the distribution of his estate.

events.title: Creation of The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust
events.description: The trust agreement for The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust was established, which is the beneficiary of Epstein's estate per his will.

events.title: Execution of Epstein's Will
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signed and executed his Last Will and Testament in the presence of witnesses and a notary public.

locations: St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands
State of New York, County of New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's will bequeaths all his property to the trustees of The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust, dated January 18, 2019.
Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn are appointed as the primary executors, each to receive $250,000 upon completion of probate.
Kathryn H. Ruemmler is designated as the successor executor if the primary executors cannot serve.
The will grants executors extensive powers to manage the estate, including investment, sale of assets, and continuation of business interests.
The document establishes Epstein's domicile as St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands, which may have implications for estate administration and taxes.
Jeffrey Epstein's Last Will and Testament was executed on January 18, 2019, approximately seven months before his death.
The will contains complex tax apportionment clauses, directing how federal and state estate taxes are to be paid from his probate estate and from assets not passing under the will or a related trust.
The document was signed and witnessed in New York and notarized by Amanda Devine, a Notary Public for the State of Florida.
The will includes a 'no contest' clause (in terrorem clause) that disinherits any beneficiary who challenges the will or trust.
The will references a separate 'Trust Agreement,' indicating a significant portion of his estate was intended to pass outside of probate.
